oai_dc:dc.dc:title: COMPARISON OF NUMERICAL AND EMPIRICAL ESTIMATES OF WAVE CONDITIONS IN THE LEE OF A DETACHED BREAKWATER
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Churchill, Jim
Taylor, David
Garber, Sean
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This paper presents a comparison of numerical and empirical methods routinely applied by practitioners to examine wave penetration in the lee of a breakwater, using a case study of a breakwater which is planned for Entrance Point, Broome in the northwest of Australia. Wave conditions representative of ambient and extreme conditions were determined from measured data captured directly offshore of the site, and an extreme cyclone metocean study (Baird, 2020). For ambient and extreme tropical cyclone conditions, waves are typically short crested at a peak period of between 4 seconds to 8 seconds. To examine the effectiveness of the offshore breakwater, empirical methods (Goda, 2000), a phase-averaged model (SWAN) and two phase-resolving model systemsâ€“ the 2D Boussinesq wave model (MIKE21BW) and 3D non-hydrostatic model (MIKE3-Wave FM) - were applied.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Coastal Engineering Proceedings; No. 37 (2022): Proceedings of 37th Conference on Coastal Engineering, Sydney, Australia, 2022; structures.63
